terms.ब्रह्म (Brahman): The Ultimate Reality, the Supreme Cosmic Power
terms.सत्यं (Satyam): Truth, the ultimate reality that exists eternally
terms.जगन्मिथ्या (Jaganmithya): The world is an illusion, the external world is not ultimately real and is transitory
terms.जीवो (Jeevo): The individual soul, the sentient being who experiences life
terms.Overall, this verse emphasizes the conce: dualism) and highlights the distinction between the ultimate reality (Brahman) and the illusory nature of the world we experience. It encourages seekers to realize their true nature as an inseparable part of Brahman and transcend the delusion of the external world.

meaning: Meaning:The verse is attributed to Adi Shankaracharya, a great philosopher of Advaita Vedanta. It states:Brahman is the ultimate reality, the supreme cosmic power that is eternal and unchanging. It represents the true nature of existence.The world that we perceive is ultimately an illusion (mithya), which means it is temporary and not ultimately real. The physical world, with all its objects and forms, is a projection of the mind and not a lasting or absolute reality.The individual soul (jeevo) refers to the individual consciousness or the sentient being who experiences life. This verse implies that the individual soul is also not ultimately real, as it is a part of the transient and illusory world.
